content.description: Algebraically, if f(x) = x^4 and g(x) = 2x + 3 then (f o g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(2x + 3) = (2x + 3)^4 and (g o f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(x^4) = 2(x^4) + 3 = 2x^4 + 3. So f(g(x)) != g(f(x)). In general, (f o g)(x) != (g o f)(x).

content.name: One-to-one function
content.description: A one-to-one function is any function where: (1) for each x there is only one value of y, and (2) for each y there is only one value of x. Equivalently, a function is one-to-one if f(a) = f(b) only when a = b. One-to-one functions satisfy both the vertical line test and the horizontal line test.
For example, f(x) = x^3 is one-to-one since it passes both the vertical line and horizontal line tests. If the function f(x) is one-to-one, it will have an inverse function which we denote f^(-1)(x).

content.name: Many-to-one function
content.description: Functions that are not one-to-one are called many-to-one. While these functions satisfy the vertical line test, they do not satisfy the horizontal line test. At least one y-value has more than one corresponding x-value. For example, f(x) = x^2 fails the horizontal line test, since if f(x) = 4 then x = -2 or 2. f(x) = x^2 is therefore many-to-one. If a function f(x) is many-to-one, it does not have an inverse function.

items: The inverse function is denoted f^(-1)(x)
The inverse must satisfy the vertical line test
The graph of the inverse is the reflection of y = f(x) in the line y = x
The inverse satisfies (f o f^(-1))(x) = x and (f^(-1) o f)(x) = x
The function y = x is called the identity function because it is its own inverse
f^(-1)(x) is the inverse of f. In general, f^(-1)(x) != 1/f(x)
If (x, y) lies on f, then (y, x) must lie on f^(-1)
The domain of f^(-1) is equal to the range of f
The range of f^(-1) is equal to the domain of f
f^(-1)(x) can be found algebraically by interchanging x and y and then making y the subject of the resulting formula

content.description: For f: y = 5x + 2 becomes f^(-1): x = 5y + 2, which we rearrange to obtain f^(-1): y = (x - 2)/5

content.problem: Consider f(x) = (1/2)x - 1. (a) Find f^(-1)(x). (b) Check that f(f^(-1)(x)) = f^(-1)(f(x)) = x. (c) Sketch y = f(x), y = f^(-1)(x), and y = x on the same set of axes.

solution.part_a: y = (1/2)x - 1 has inverse function x = (1/2)y - 1 {interchanging x and y}. Therefore 2x = y - 2, so y = 2x + 2. Thus f^(-1)(x) = 2x + 2

content.problem: Consider f: x -> 2x + 3. (a) On the same axes, graph f and its inverse function f^(-1). (b) Find f^(-1)(x) using: (i) coordinate geometry and the gradient of y = f^(-1)(x) from part a, (ii) variable interchange. (c) Check that (f o f^(-1))(x) = (f^(-1) o f)(x) = x

solution.part_a: f(x) = 2x + 3 passes through (0, 3) and (2, 7). Therefore f^(-1)(x) passes through (3, 0) and (7, 2). If f includes point (a, b) then f^(-1) includes point (b, a).
solution.part_b_i: y = f^(-1)(x) has gradient (2 - 0)/(7 - 3) = 1/2. Its equation is (y - 0)/(x - 3) = 1/2, so y = (x - 3)/2. Therefore f^(-1)(x) = (x - 3)/2
solution.part_b_ii: f is y = 2x + 3, so f^(-1) is x = 2y + 3. Therefore x - 3 = 2y, so (x - 3)/2 = y. Thus f^(-1)(x) = (x - 3)/2

content.description: Linear and quadratic functions are the first members of a family called the polynomials. The polynomials can all be written in the form y = a_0 + a_1*x + a_2*x^2 + a_3*x^3 + .... When a polynomial is divided by another polynomial, we call it a rational function.
A reciprocal function is a function of the form y = k/x, k != 0. The graph of a reciprocal function is called a rectangular hyperbola.

content.name: Properties of y = 1/x
items: y = 1/x is undefined when x = 0, so the domain is {x | x != 0}
On a sign diagram, this value is indicated with a dashed line
The graph includes two asymptotes, which are lines the graph approaches but never reaches
x = 0 is a vertical asymptote: as x -> 0^-, 1/x -> -infinity; as x -> 0^+, 1/x -> infinity
y = 0 is a horizontal asymptote: as x -> infinity, 1/x -> 0^+; as x -> -infinity, 1/x -> 0^-

content.description: The reciprocal function y = k/x passes through the points (1, k), (k, 1), (-1, -k), and (-k, -1).

topics.name: Rational Functions of the Form y = (ax + b)/(cx + d)

items: For a function written in the form y = b/(cx + d) + a where b, c != 0: the vertical asymptote is x = -d/c, the horizontal asymptote is y = a
For a function written in the form y = (ax + b)/(cx + d) where c != 0: the vertical asymptote is x = -d/c, the horizontal asymptote is y = a/c

content.problem: Consider the function y = 6/(x - 2) + 4. (a) Find the asymptotes of the function. (b) Find the axes intercepts. (c) Use technology to help sketch the function, including the features found in parts a and b.

solution.part_a: The vertical asymptote is x = 2. The horizontal asymptote is y = 4.
solution.part_b: When y = 0, 6/(x - 2) = -4, so -4(x - 2) = 6, -4x + 8 = 6, -4x = -2, x = 1/2. When x = 0, y = 6/(-2) + 4 = 1. So the x-intercept is 1/2 and the y-intercept is 1.

content.solution: (x - 1)/(2x + 1) is zero when x = 1 and undefined when x = -1/2. When x = 10, (x - 1)/(2x + 1) = 9/21 > 0. Since (x - 1) and (2x + 1) are single factors, the signs alternate.

content.problem: Consider the function f(x) = (2x + 1)/(x - 1). (a) Find the vertical asymptote of the function. (b) Find the axes intercepts. (c) Rearrange the function to find the horizontal asymptote. (d) Draw a sign diagram of the function. (e) Hence discuss the behaviour of the function near the asymptotes. (f) Sketch the function, showing the features you have found.

solution.part_b: f(0) = 1/(-1) = -1, so the y-intercept is -1. f(x) = 0 when 2x + 1 = 0, therefore x = -1/2. The x-intercept is -1/2.
solution.part_c: f(x) = (2x + 1)/(x - 1) = (2(x - 1) + 3)/(x - 1) = 2 + 3/(x - 1). The horizontal asymptote is y = 2.
solution.part_d: Sign diagram shows signs alternate with critical points at x = -1/2 and x = 1.
solution.part_e: As x -> 1^-, f(x) -> -infinity. As x -> 1^+, f(x) -> infinity. As x -> -infinity, f(x) -> 2^-. As x -> infinity, f(x) -> 2^+. As |x| -> infinity, the fraction 3/(x-1) becomes infinitely small.
